Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Exploring novel leaf phenology of invading shrubs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Invasive shrubs are a major concern in eastern U.S. forests where their success is at the cost of native species diversity and tree regeneration. One of the reasons invasive shrubs may impact native ecosystems so greatly is that they have an extended period with leaves, as compared to native woody species, also called extended leaf phenology (ELP). Phenology is the timing of biological phenomena that correspond to climatic conditions. This earlier leaf emergence in the spring and/or later leaf fall in the autumn creates shade at unique times of the year. So far, studies comparing ELP of invasive compared to native shrubs have been done at single locations. However, we know that cues that drive leaf phenology, for example temperature, vary greatly from region to region and from year to year. So, when we compare regions across the eastern U.S., will we find differences in leaf phenology between native and invasive shrubs? Are there regions where it is important to focus management efforts because ELP of invading shrubs is greater? How will leaf phenology change with temperature changes? To address these questions, researchers have developed a citizen science campaign called "Shady Invaders" to collect leaf phenology observations across the eastern U.S. Through participant training and eNewsletter and webinar updates, both the public and scientific research are enriched from this collaboration.


Species-specific leaf phenology data are impossible to collect simultaneously across a regional scale without numerous observers. Fortunately, data collection is straightforward, allowing the growing efforts of citizen scientists to be applied to this problem. Regional citizen science phenology observations for native and invasive shrubs will provide insight into the spatial extent and consistency of the novel leaf phenology of invasive shrubs across eastern U.S. and will contribute to our understanding of the broader applicability of local-scale research on this topic. The landscape-scale, multi-year approach can be used to predict the potential implications of climate change for leaf phenology by developing a predictive model for phenology. Through collaboration with researchers from China, phenology data are being incorporated from the native range of the shrub species invading forests of eastern U.S. to understand whether novel phenology arose as a product of evolutionary pressures in the native range (pre-adaptation), or more recently in the introduced range (rapid adaptation with range expansion). This will contribute to pressing research questions as well as informing whether leaf phenology is a useful tool for predicting and preventing future invasions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Invasive shrubs are a major concern in eastern U.S. forests. In these ecosystems, invasive shrub success is at the cost of native species abundance, diversity and tree regeneration. One of the reasons invasive shrubs may impact native ecosystems so greatly is an extended period with leaves that is not seen in native woody species, also called extended leaf phenology. This earlier leaf emergence in the spring and/or later leaf fall in the autumn creates shade in the understory at unique times of the year when the overstory tree canopy does not have leaves. Studies quantifying the extended leaf phenology of invasive compared to native shrubs at different sites have produced conflicting results. Invasive shrubs may have leaves much longer in some places than in others because cues like temperature that drive leaf phenology vary greatly from region to region and from year to year. So, how different is leaf phenology in one region compared to another? Are there regions where it is important to focus management because this difference is greater? To address these questions required a large number of observers spread across the eastern U.S recording leaf phenology during the same seasons. Consequently, researchers developed a regional citizen science campaign in partnership with the USA National Phenology Network. Through participant training, eNewsletters, and webinar updates, both the public and scientific research were enriched from this collaboration. With the help of over 300 citizen scientists, researchers found that the difference between native and invasive shrubs can exceed 70 days within a growing season. Furthermore, this gap decreases with increasing latitude: 2.9 [1.6, 4.2; 95% confidence interval] days per degree northward in the spring, and 2.2 [0.6,1.9] in the fall. Geographic patterns in extended leaf phenology have implications for policy and management. The magnitude of extended leaf phenology could help inform state and local policy limiting the sale and distribution of species where they have the greatest extended leaf phenology compared to native shrubs, and may serve as a tool to identify invasion potential of new horticultural specimen. Additionally, extended leaf phenology makes invasive shrubs an easier “green target” in the spring and fall. Targeting windows of time when only invasive shrubs have high-visibility green foliage simplifies early detection surveys and minimizes native species damage during removal efforts - especially those involving foliar herbicide applications, because native species lack foliage at that time.

Why do we find differences between native and invasive shrubs? Researchers found that spring warmth, a metric commonly used for modeling spring leaf phenology and sensitive to climate change, appears to influence native and invasive shrubs similarly. However, native and invasive shrubs respond very differently to the number of chill days (days between 0 and 10 degrees C) during the dormant season, another important cue for the timing of leaf emergence. Therefore, the influence of chill days and how it may change under future climate scenarios requires further research.

Overall, citizen science observations for this project have expanded the data publicly available through the USA National Phenology Network, while promoting teaching, training and learning of participants. Their high-quality observations were instrumental for quantifying and understanding the extended leaf phenology of invasive shrubs at a regional scale. Results have been broadly disseminated to citizen scientists, the general public, natural resource managers, and scientific researchers across disciplines through several oral presentations (e.g. https://tinyurl.com/u72bync), social media, magazine and journal articles and upcoming scientific journal publication.
